title: G.3. Sage Nandisen
subtitle: A devoted sage, Nandisen, is tested by a demigod disguised as an ailing monk, showcasing his unwavering tolerance, compassion, and contentment.

storyContent.tagHTML: Praise in Heaven, Test on Earth

Sage Nandisen was a great ascetic and well versed in scriptures. He took a vow to serve other monks with utmost devotion. His devotion in serving the monks was popular even in the heavenly abode. One day, Indra commended his services during an assembly of demigods. One of the demigods was surprised at such high praise for a mere mortal. Therefore, he decided to see the worthiness of Sage Nandisen.
The Call for Help

The demigod arrived at the outskirts of the village and assumed the form of two monks, one very old and injured and the other young and healthy. Sage Nandisen had just returned from collecting Gochari (alms) and was about to break his fast when the young monk came to him and said, “Oh blessed one! There is a very old monk suffering from diarrhea, extreme thirst, and hunger. He is weak and needs your help.”
Hearing these words, Sage Nandisen immediately got up, took clean water, and went to the old monk.
Trials of Patience
Seeing Nandisen, the old monk raged, “Oh you wretch, I am lying here suffering and you did not even care to see if anyone needs help.”

Sage Nandisen was not offended by these words due to his virtues of tolerance, forgiveness, and compassion. He calmly replied, “Oh, the best of monks, kindly excuse my oversight. I have brought clean water for you to drink.”

He helped the old monk drink the water, and then cleaned his clothes, his body, and helped him sit up. The old monk again became irritated. He frowned, “Oh you fool, do you not see that I am too weak to sit? What are you doing to me?”
The Difficult Journey

Sage Nandisen replied politely, “I will help you.” After helping the old monk sit up, he said, “Oh revered monk, if you desire, I shall carry you to the Upäshray (a place where monks stay temporarily) where you will be more comfortable.”
The monk replied, “Why are you asking me? You may do so if you wish.”
Sage Nandisen therefore seated the monk on his shoulders and slowly proceeded towards the Upäshray. He walked slowly, watching every step carefully.
Unwavering Service

The demigod was determined to test him, so he vomited, urinated, and defecated on Sage Nandisen. The old monk said, “Oh you wretch, what is wrong with you? Can’t you see that I am sitting in my own filth? Is this the way to serve the sick?”
Despite the old monk’s actions and his harsh words, Sage Nandisen was not disturbed at all. He said, “Pardon me. Let me clean your clothes again.”

After cleaning the monk’s clothes, Sage Nandisen also cleaned his clothes and made sure the old monk was comfortable. Then he continued walking and took care not to offend the monk with any more of his actions. On the way, he thought of ways to cure the monk. During all this, the old monk was watching Sage Nandisen and did not see any change in the helping nature of the sage even after all the aggravation.
The Revelation

When they arrived at the Upäshray, the old monk turned back into an angel and bowed down at once to Sage Nandisen, saying, “You are blessed. Oh Sage, you are the illustration of a real monk. You deserve all the praise given by Indra. I am very pleased with you and will grant you whatever you wish.”
A Sage's Contentment

“Oh, heavenly angel, this human life is very precious. Nothing is more valuable than human existence. I am content. I crave nothing,” said Sage Nandisen. The heavenly angel bowed his head at the feet of the Sage and returned to his abode, applauding the merits of the Sage.
Moral of the Story

This story teaches us the importance of tolerance, discipline, and contentment which are all fundamental values of Jainism. First and foremost, Sage Nandisen chose to devote his life to serving monks, an admirable goal requiring the utmost level of dedication and discipline. He demonstrated his tolerance and willingness to serve others without even knowing that the demigod was testing him. This means that he was truly dedicated to monks and believed in what he was doing. He also indicated his contentment with the human life when asked for a wish. This contentment is symbolic of the principle of non-possessiveness.

events.title: Indra's Praise & Demigod's Skepticism
events.description: Indra praises Sage Nandisen's devotion in a heavenly assembly; a demigod becomes skeptical and decides to test him.

events.title: Demigod's Disguise and Arrival
events.description: The demigod arrives near the village and assumes the forms of a very old, injured monk and a young, healthy monk.

events.title: Young Monk's Plea to Nandisen
events.description: The young monk (demigod) approaches Sage Nandisen, who is about to break his fast, and informs him of the suffering old monk.

events.title: Nandisen's Immediate Response & Care
events.description: Sage Nandisen immediately abandons his meal, takes clean water, goes to the old monk, and despite the monk's rebukes, calmly offers water, cleans him, and helps him sit up.

events.title: Offer to Carry to Upäshray
events.description: Sage Nandisen politely offers to carry the old monk to the Upäshray for better comfort, which the monk passively accepts.

events.title: Extreme Tests During Journey
events.description: While being carried, the demigod (as old monk) vomits, urinates, and defecates on Sage Nandisen and verbally abuses him.

events.title: Nandisen's Unwavering Composure
events.description: Sage Nandisen remains completely undisturbed, cleans the monk and himself again, and continues the journey with care, thinking of ways to cure the monk.

events.title: Arrival and Divine Revelation
events.description: Upon reaching the Upäshray, the old monk transforms back into a radiant angel (demigod) and bows to Sage Nandisen, praising his virtue.

events.title: Wish Offered and Declined
events.description: The angel offers Sage Nandisen any wish, but the sage expresses complete contentment with human life and craves nothing.

events.title: Angel's Departure and Acclaim
events.description: The angel bows to Sage Nandisen and returns to the heavenly abode, applauding the sage's merits.

charactersData.name: Sage Nandisen
charactersData.description: A great ascetic, well-versed in scriptures, who took a vow to serve other monks with utmost devotion. He exemplifies tolerance, forgiveness, compassion, and contentment.

charactersData.name: Indra
charactersData.description: King of the heavenly gods, who commended Sage Nandisen's services in an assembly of demigods.

charactersData.name: Demigod (Tester/Angel)
charactersData.description: Initially surprised by Indra's praise for a mortal, this demigod decided to test Sage Nandisen. Later, impressed by the sage's virtue, he appeared as an angel and offered a wish.

charactersData.name: Old Monk (Disguise)
charactersData.description: The form of a very old, injured, and irritable monk assumed by the demigod to test Sage Nandisen's patience and devotion.

charactersData.name: Young Monk (Disguise)
charactersData.description: The form of a young, healthy monk assumed by the demigod to inform Sage Nandisen about the (fictional) suffering old monk.

quizData.question: Why did one of the demigods decide to test Sage Nandisen?
options: Indra ordered the test.
The demigod was bored.
He was surprised at Indra's high praise for a mere mortal and wanted to see his worthiness.
Sage Nandisen had challenged the demigods.
quizData.answer: He was surprised at Indra's high praise for a mere mortal and wanted to see his worthiness.
quizData.explanation: The demigod was skeptical of Indra's commendation of Sage Nandisen and decided to verify the sage's virtues personally.

quizData.question: What was Sage Nandisen about to do when the young monk (demigod in disguise) approached him?
options: Meditate
Teach scriptures
Break his fast after collecting alms
Go to sleep
quizData.answer: Break his fast after collecting alms
quizData.explanation: Sage Nandisen had just returned from collecting Gochari (alms) and was about to break his fast when he was informed about the supposedly suffering monk.

quizData.question: How did Sage Nandisen react to the old monk's initial harsh words and accusations?
options: He became angry and argued back.
He ignored the monk and left.
He was not offended and calmly offered help, excusing his perceived oversight.
He reported the monk to the authorities.
quizData.answer: He was not offended and calmly offered help, excusing his perceived oversight.
quizData.explanation: Due to his virtues of tolerance, forgiveness, and compassion, Sage Nandisen remained calm and continued his efforts to serve the monk.

quizData.question: What extreme actions did the demigod (disguised as the old monk) take while Sage Nandisen was carrying him?
options: He praised Sage Nandisen continuously.
He fell asleep.
He vomited, urinated, and defecated on Sage Nandisen.
He offered Sage Nandisen gifts.
quizData.answer: He vomited, urinated, and defecated on Sage Nandisen.
quizData.explanation: To further test Sage Nandisen's patience and commitment, the demigod subjected him to these unpleasant acts.

quizData.question: What did Sage Nandisen say when the angel (demigod in his true form) offered him any wish?
options: He asked for wealth and power.
He asked for a place in heaven.
He said he was content and craved nothing, valuing human existence.
He asked for the angel to serve him.
quizData.answer: He said he was content and craved nothing, valuing human existence.
quizData.explanation: Sage Nandisen demonstrated his contentment and understanding of the preciousness of human life by declining any material or heavenly boons.

graphicsData.title: Praise in the Heavens
graphicsData.description: In his celestial court, Indra, king of the gods, commends the unparalleled devotion of a mortal, Sage Nandisen, sparking curiosity and doubt in another demigod.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A king on a heavenly throne speaking to an assembly of angels, one of whom looks skeptical.

graphicsData.title: An Unkind Greeting
graphicsData.description: Answering a call for help, Sage Nandisen is met not with gratitude but with harsh insults from the disguised demigod, testing his patience from the very start.
graphicsData.imageAlt: An old, sickly monk yelling at a calm, composed monk who is offering him water.

graphicsData.title: The Ultimate Test
graphicsData.description: While being carried on Nandisen's shoulders, the disguised monk vomits and defecates on him. Yet, the Sage's expression remains one of pure, undisturbed compassion.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk carrying another on his shoulders, remaining serene even as he is being defiled.

graphicsData.title: The Angel Revealed
graphicsData.description: His test failed, the demigod reveals his true, radiant angelic form and bows in reverence to the sage whose virtue he could not break.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A glowing angel bowing at the feet of a simple, humble monk.

graphicsData.title: A Wish Refused
graphicsData.description: When offered any boon he desires, Sage Nandisen calmly refuses, explaining that he is content and craves nothing, embodying the principle of non-possessiveness.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk gently gesturing 'no' to an angel who is offering a glowing gift.

graphicsData.title: Serving with Devotion
graphicsData.description: Sage Nandisen's life was defined by his core vow: to serve his fellow monks with complete devotion, no matter the personal cost.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk tenderly washing the feet of another, older monk.
